hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: A shepherd asked the Prophet ﷺ, and he said: May I pray near the places where camels rest (their dwelling places)? He said: No. So may I pray in the places where sheep rest? He said: Yes. Zayd ibn Ali said: There is no harm in praying on a mat and on bare ground. And Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The least a man may wear to pray is his garment, and the least a woman may wear to pray is a shirt and a headscarf. And Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: A female slave may pray without a headscarf.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ came, and it was said to him: Indeed, Abdullah ibn Rawahah, may Allah be pleased with him, is gravely ill, so he came to him while he was unconscious. Abdullah ibn Rawahah said: O Messenger of Allah, I was unconscious for three days. What should I do about the prayers? The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Pray the prayer of the day you awakened, for it is sufficient for you. Zayd said: Regarding the unconscious person, if he was unconscious for less than three days, he repeats all of them. If he was unconscious for three days or more, he repeats only the prayers with limited time windows. If he awakens before Maghrib, he repeats Zuhr and Asr. If he awakens before Fajr, he repeats Maghrib and Isha. And this is the explanation of the Prophet's ﷺ saying to Abdullah ibn Rawahah: Repeat the prayers of your day.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ entered upon a man from the Ansar who was seized by wind (paralyzed). He said: O Messenger of Allah, how should I pray? He said: If you can sit him, sit him, otherwise direct him towards the Qibla and command him to gesture with indication and make his prostration lower than his ruku'. If he cannot recite the Quran, recite near him and make him hear. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The sick person prays standing. If he cannot, then sitting, and he bows and prostrates on the ground. If he cannot, then he gestures with indication. He said: He does not prostrate on a stick, nor on a fan, nor on a pillow. And Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: A standing person does not pray behind a sick person who is praying seated.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to recite Surah Al-Sajdah (Chapter 32) in the Fajr prayer on Friday, then prostrate. He would magnify when he prostrated and when he raised his head. In the second rak'ah he recited: Has there not come upon man a period of time (Chapter 76). [Second chain:] From his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: He used to pray after Friday two rak'ahs, then four, then return and rest. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The call (Adhan) on Friday is when the Imam ascends the minbar, and when he descends the Muezzin gives the Iqamah. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Imam speaks loudly in recitation on Friday and does not perform Qunut. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Friday prayer is only obligatory on the people of cities. Whoever is outside the city, Friday is not obligatory on him unless he hears the call, in which case it becomes obligatory. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Friday prayer is not obligatory on a slave, nor on a sick person, nor on a woman, nor on a traveler.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: He used to pray with the people in Fitr (Eid al-Fitr) and Adha (Eid al-Adha) two rak'ahs. He would begin then magnify, then recite, then magnify five times, then magnify once more and ruku' with it. Then he would stand in the second rak'ah, recite, then magnify four times, then magnify once more and ruku' with it. That is twelve Takbirs (glorifications). He would speak loudly in recitation and would not pray anything before it or after it.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: When two Eids fell on the same day, he prayed with the people in the open field, then said after his sermon: We will gather after noon (Zuhr prayer). Whoever wishes to attend, that is Allah's favor which He bestows upon whom He wills, and whoever leaves it, there is no sin on him. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: If you miss the Imam in the Eid prayer or Friday prayer, pray four rak'ahs. Zayd ibn Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Whoever catches the Imam bowing in Friday or Eid prayer before he bows in the second rak'ah of Eid prayer, he prays two rak'ahs. If he catches him after he raises his head from ruku', he prays four rak'ahs.
